segments.text: 13th, 1984, in the home of Roy Benavides, a Vietnam veteran.
Chest one, two, three, chest one, two, three.
Your life, how you, where you started and how you decided to go into the service and this type of thing?
Well, I was born in Quirrell, right outside of Quirrell, in a small farm.
in 1935, on August 5th.
And our parents, my brother and I, were orphans.
Our parents died at an early age.
And then after our parents died, we were adopted by an uncle named Hernel Campo.
My brother and I came here in the mid-40s.
And we started school here.
I started school.
And I lettered and tracked.
And I was a Golden Glover, two-year Golden Glover for the state of Texas.
I fought in Will Rogers Coliseum in Dallas.
And then I decided to quit school.
I was advised not to.
My teachers, who still live here,
I thought that I had a good head on my shoulder, and they didn't want to see me quit, but I was determined to make it out on my own.
However, I could see that I need the education, but I was seeking adventure in a way that I was looking for some certain love, not that my
My adopted parents didn't give it to me, but I guess the good Lord just selects people with this instinct.
There was something you were searching for.
Yes.
And so I dropped out of school in the eighth grade, seventh grade, and I ran away from home.
And I got hungry and came back.
And I think I ran away a second time.
but they caught me.
And I was just searching for an adventure.
I was just, I guess I was just that self-made youngster, you know, that had a mind of his own, that could turn things the way he wanted to.
And I just couldn't wait to grow up.
And the uniform fascinated me.
This was something that I admired.
looking at the World War II veterans and the Korean veterans when they came back.
And I knew that this was for me.
And I just couldn't wait to join some sort of branch of the service.
But then I was told that I needed an education.
Well, that in mind,
I decided to join the Texas National Guard if they would accept it, which they did later when I became of age.
But I had one goal in mind to seek an education in the high school diploma because I was told during those years that I was seeking enlistment in the military that without an education,
And without a diploma, I didn't have a future.
So that goes to say that without either, you don't have, that's the key to success.
You don't have anything.
And I had talked it over with my uncle, with my adoptive father who was disciplinary.
So you found out that education was going to be an important part
Very important.
Well, later in the years.
But you know, I was just a wild youngster.
And I guess I was seeking a career and an adventure.
But I didn't know the steps to look into this.
And thank God that I had a lot of friends that took a lot of interest in me here in El Campo and in the military.
especially here, I joined the Texas National Guard.
I had a job, you know, had a job, and I was doing good.
But I joined the Texas National Guard because I wanted to have the feeling of the uniform.
I wanted the challenge, you know, to be given orders, to see if I could cope with wearing the uniform.
And that is a great challenge, you know.

In the Texas National Guard, which I advise anyone now to join any unit, reserve or Texas National Guard, Air Force, Guard, you go to summer camp for two weeks, you know, you become a soldier for two weeks.
You become a soldier in active duty once a month, you know, and then you go on maneuvers.
And this, I was breaking myself into to being what I wanted to be.
And I liked it.
And after two years, well, I went to school to Fort Knox, Kentucky.
And I got to live in a regular military barracks with regular army men and everything.
And hearing the trumpets, you know, go up and
and playing Reveille at 6 o'clock in the morning and playing tab to 10 o'clock at night, Lifetime and everything.
And I just loved it.
And this was for me.
This was for me.
Military life was like a second love for you.
Yeah, so I just couldn't wait to just come back and say, hey, look, I want to join the Red Army.
But then, when I was there at Fort Knox, Kentucky, on active duty,
I met some paratroopers.
And here in El Campo, I met some, uh, Mr. Kinehart, Colonel Kinehart and, uh, and, uh, Garrett and Mr.
Colonel Garrett and, and others that had been in the Airborne during World War II in Korea.
And I wanted to join the Airborne.
I wanted to be a paratrooper because I learned
that the more qualifications you have, the better off you'll be if you're going to make the Army career.
However, you need that education.
You need that high school diploma.
And I just couldn't wait to get back to El Campo to quit the National Guard to go back into active duty.
And I did.
I came back and I told my uncle, of course, you know, I come from a very disciplinary family.
My uncle was the deputy sheriff of Horton County for over 30 years.
I'm calling him .
And you had to be of age, you know, to leave that.
The old Hispanic costume, you know, had to be 21 years of age.
Heck, even the older brothers, cousins, they were 21, 22, they didn't even smoke in front of me.
You know, that's how much respect we had for one another.
And the girls, they didn't date.
So... A lot of things have changed today, haven't they?
Oh, my God.
A tremendous change.
I guess you might say it was a turnover.
Complete turnover.
Turnaround.
180 degrees.
So when I came back, you know, I just casually...
told my uncle that I was going to the active duty.
But I had one goal in mind.
How old were you when you went into active duty?
I was 18, 18 when I went to active duty.
And I had that one goal in mind to keep my high school diploma.
Which it turned out to be, I had, I'd say rough times.
The military
or the airborne, or ranger trained, or special forces, whatever training.
It's only as hard as you want it to be.
Well, back then, was there much discrimination toward being that you were Hispanic or toward black?
Was there a lot of discrimination, or was the military?
Well, there was.
But not as much as in civilian life?
Well, there was.
In some way, you could feel it, but then you were in uniform.
Because remember, you take an oath.
And any man that takes an oath to serve his country, to take orders from officers or non-commissioned officers, there is a pride within him.
So therefore, irregardless whether you come from the South, North,
or east or west, you know, you have that pride and you took that oath.
I saw some discrimination, and I felt some at times, but I've proven to myself and to others, you know, that I was a defender of this country and I'm an American.
And I felt proud to be an American.
I served with some, so to speak, rednecks,
And I served with some blacks that hated redneck.
And I served with some Hispanics that hate Hispanic.
Not hate, but then they were what we would call in those days coconuts.
Brown on the outside and white on the inside.
And I served with all of them.
The presentation that you make to this individual, the professionalism that you display, I have a plaque right there that I committed a very serious offense one day at one time.
And it was so serious that I could have gone to jail.
I could have been going to the penitentiary for 15 years.
And I have lived by that motto of duty, honor, and country.
And I later found out what that duty, honor, and country meant.
That a man should not cheat, lie, or steal, or tolerate those that do.
And that was me.
That, to me, was what I was looking for in the military.
And that is the motto of Westman, a cadet in the military academy.
So I have lived by that.
And now I'm an adopted graduate of that academy.
I have a saber, a graduated saber.
To become a professional soldier is something that I always look forward to, just like anyone else here in life.
You know, you're a student.
You want to be the best, and I hope you'll be.
Any individual that seeks employment in General Motors, or IHOP, or CP&L, he's going to be the best.
And he's going to live by some standards that he sets.
And he sets his goals, and he's going to reach them.
Well, I set my goals, and I set my standards.
And I set a model that I live by.
I did.
How long were you in the service before you went to Vietnam?
Well, let's see.
I joined the National Guard in 1951 and 1952, later part of 1951.
And I joined the active duty in 1955.
And I completed basic training.
Then I went to Korea in later part of 1955.
Where did you do your basics?
I went through Beckett training at Fort Royal, California, and at Fort Carson, Colorado.
In fact, in Fort Carson, I met...
I met also the...
Tony Morton?
No, not Tony Morton.
The manager for the New York Giants.
He was a hop head.
I mean a hard head.
Excuse me.
And Farron Young, I met him there.
He was taking back the training.
And then I went to Korea in the latter part of 1955.
I came back in 58 and I went to Berlin, to Honey Anchor, and I served there 57, 58.
I came back in 59 and I met the lady, Elvis Presley, in Orchapa, Arkansas.
And he was going to Beijing train there, getting a haircut.
I imagine that was a shock for him.
Well, I didn't even know that he'd become a star.
And then from there, I went to Fort Gordon, Georgia, a military police school.
I graduated second in my class.

And incidentally, the men that I was supposed to graduate first, but because of my professionalism, I guess, because of the standards that I've set, and they couldn't, my men couldn't follow or meet up to them, I got some physical contact with one of them, and so that kept me from
being the first undergraduate.
And my buddy, Arnie Treville, who graduated first, he's an FBI agent.
I served with the military police in Fort Bowen, Georgia.
Then I drove for the commander in general.
I was selected to drive for him.
Then I went airborne.
I remember what the non-commissioned officer told me about the more qualifications you have, the better off you are in the military.
And I was going to school during those times.
I was going to take in my GED.
But because of duty, you know, and going out to the field and everything, that was kind of hard.
And I only had a few more, oh, I guess about eight hours
to get my diploma.
And I put in for airborne, which I always wanted to go airborne.
But because I was driving for the commanding general, I didn't have the time.
And I finally got accepted to go airborne, to go to the 82nd Airborne Division of Fort Bend, North Carolina.
And then I was married in 1959.
In fact, today, we were just talking about the date, because we just had some friends celebrating the 20th anniversary.
And I couldn't remember my date.
So please don't ask me.
I think it was June the 7th in 1959.
And we lived in Fort Bragg, North Carolina for 15 years, off and on.
I was stationed there with 82nd Airborne Division.
I finally completed my high school and I got my diploma.
And then I joined the Special Forces, the Green Berets, which later was known as the Green Berets.
Then it wasn't when they were training.
I went through some real rough, rough training.
But I enjoyed it and I loved it.
The better, the harder it was, the better I loved it.
Then I went to, well, I traveled to the South and went to the United States on assignment, often on a train assignment.
I went to Vietnam in 1955, as an advisor.
And I was an advisor to a Vietnamese infantry battalion, airborne infantry battalion.
One of the very hardest jobs that I ever had.
I say hard is because I didn't know the language and I knew my job, but it was hard to perform your duties through an interpreter to other people and to live their life, to follow their customs.
It was very hard.
We were in the war, the United States was committed.
And then the United States would not accept our presence there.
So this was entirely different for professional soldiers.
Did the soldiers over there, how did they feel about, you know, because most of the people in America were against the war, you know.
Was it hard on the morale of the soldiers in Vietnam?
It was hard in a way in terms of the war that
the American people had no support for us.
And to us, it seems that we're just as Americans as they are.
And here we are here, and my uncle and aunt, my father and mother would not accept me, would not come back again.
You know, I feel like a traitor.
I feel like, hey,
Jerk, what are you doing in your uniform?

You know, all the other soldiers returning from World War I and World War II, everybody came back and there was, you know, but the Vietnam soldiers didn't get the same reception, did they, as the other soldiers from the other wars?
No, we didn't get that same respect.
But, you know, in later times, I've learned that the American public, that the American people,
They just got too much education, not enough common sense.
Do you think the media has a lot... Well, uh... Has...can...can... You know, make the...
The news media, yeah.
They did that in a sense, but let me tell you.
The news media was spreading the word out only according to what the public wanted to hear.

You know, I work with intelligence, and I don't want to give myself away, because with the Green Berets, you know, we talked, we, uh, held a lot, we conducted a lot of international missions and everything.
But this, this society, this modern society, knew what we were doing.
They wouldn't accept it because
The legislators would not let the public know exactly what they wanted us to do there.
Nobody knew the real reason y'all were there.
It was the legislators in Washington that committed us there, which the public was entitled to know where we were committed to because
They are the taxpayers.
They are the people that elect the legislature.
You know, at times, I just wonder, of course, I'm writing my autobiography now, and part of it will come in my story, but I just wonder if any of these big corporations didn't have so much interest
It was big money for them.
That's right.
And so, in a way, we were protecting their interests.
War always meant money for the industry.
Yeah, because of the reproduction of material and everything.
The economy always went up during a war.
you know, the extra production of materials needed.
